dataset.title: New York Citizens Statewide Lake Assessment Program (CSLAP), 1985-2011

creator.organizationName: Bureau of Watershed Assessment and Monitoring, Division of Water with the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation
creator.positionName: Chief- Lake Monitoring and Assessment Section

address.deliveryPoint: Bureau of Water Assessment and Management NYSDEC Division of Water 625 Broadway, 4th Floor

abstract.para: CSLAP is New York’s Citizens Statewide Lake Assessment Program. CSLAP is a volunteer lake monitoring and education program that is managed by the NY Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) and New York State Federation of Lake Associations (NYSFOLA). The program has delivered high quality data to many DEC programs for over 25 years. It includes data from 259 lakes (21 of which have 2 or more sampling points/lake). Virtually all lakes have multiple years of data, and many have 20+ years, although most have years that lack data. Samples are collected by trained citizen monitors, and sent to a State or state-approved lab. Analyses prior to 2002 were done by the NY Dept of Health, and subsequently at a State-Certified Lab. The program is extremely well documented, and an overview of the background and details of the program are described in Kishbaugh (1988).

intellectualRights.para: This information is released to the public under the Creative Commons license CC0 1.0 Universal (https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/) and may be used for academic, educational, or commercial purposes subject to the following restrictions: The Data User must realize that these data sets are being actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the data creators or contacts. Where appropriate, the Data User may be encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators. The Data User must realize that the data may be misinterpreted if taken out of context. The Data User must acknowledge use of the data by an appropriate citation (suggested format includes the DOI). While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is". The creators shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of data sets. Data users should be aware that we periodically update data sets. By using these data, the Data User agrees to abide by the terms of this agreement. Thank you for your cooperation.

address.deliveryPoint: Bureau of Water Assessment and Management NYSDEC Division of Water 625 Broadway, 4th Floor

section.title: QA/QC
section.para: EPA QA/QC protocols were used, and NY DEC also conducted parallel sample collection and analysis side-by-side with volunteers to evaluate data reliability (along with other QA/QC tests; see Kishbaugh 1988).

section.title: Field protocol
section.para: Field protocols are described in detail in CSLAP Sampling Protocol.pdf
Sample depth was recorded with most observations

section.title: Chemical analyses and detection limits
section.para: Samples are collected by trained citizen monitors, and sent to a State or state-approved lab. Analyses prior to 2002 were done by the NY Dept of Health, and subsequently at a State-Certified Lab
Filter- 0.45 um for dissolved constituents
Tot.P - SM 18-20 4500-P E
LOQ- 0.0047 mgP/l; LOD- 0.0012 mgP/L (prior to 2002, detection limit = 0.002 mg/l)
NOx- USEPA 353.2 Rev 2.0
LOQ- 0.041mgN/L; LOD- 0.010 mgN/L (prior to 1988, NOx detection limit = 0.05
mg/l; from 1988 to 2002, NOx detection limit = 0.02 mgN/L)
NH4 – USEPA 350.1 Rev 2.0
LOQ- 0.041mgN/L; LOD- 0.010 mgN/L
EHS adds- prior to 2002, detection limit = 0.01 mg/L
TN – SM 20 4500-N C
LOQ- 0.307 mgN/L; LOD- 0.084 mgN/L
TColor – EPA 110.2
LOQ- 8 CU; LOD- 3 CU
TColor- values below detection limit indicated by “<LOD”
LOQ- 0.01 uS/cm; LOD- 0.01 uS/cm
LOQ- 0.7 mgCa/L; LOD- 0.2 mgCa/L
Calcium was not analyzed through CSLAP prior to 2002
Chl.a - USEPA 445.0 Rev. 1.2
LOQ- 0.3 ugChl/L; LOD- 0.1 ugChl/L

section.title: Missing values
section.para: Missing values are most commonly indicated by an empty cell.
#VALUE! = Unclear if these indicate values below detection limit or some other irregularity.
Variables related to lake or sampling depth (Zbot, Zsd, Zsamp)
•Missing values = not rec, not recorded, or NA

•Estimated depths or depths greater than could be measured: denoted by a “~” or “+” or “>”associated with the depth value, or the words surface and bottom in quotes. Note that there is no consistent ‘limit of detection’ for depth across lakes. Very deep lakes where these estimates show up include Canada Lake, Cayuga Lake, DeRuyter Reservoir
•Other terms used include deep, hypo, epi, shore, same (and sometimes any of these terms were entered in quotes)

samplingDescription.para: Sampling occurs 8 times per season, and the season is typically summer months. In earlier years, sampling frequency was occasionally more frequent.

dataTable.entityDescription: New York Citizens Statewide Lake Assessment Program (CSLAP), 1985-2011

attribute.attributeDefinition: CSLAP ID Number- assigned by NYSDEC
surface (1.5 m from water surface) or bottom (1.5 m above lake bottom) water sample

otherEntity.entityDescription: Imports data for the LAke multi-scaled GeOSpatial database (LAGOS)
